Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Low-Cost and Highly Efficient Hydrogen Production from Water Splitting
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be the development and commercialization of a green hydrogen production technology. The proposed technology will benefit the water splitting manufacturers who currently suffer from high manufacturing costs associated with expensive catalyst materials and manufacturing, low efficiency, and short lifetime in operation. The technology also will benefit pure-hydrogen consumers who suffer from the impurities in current hydrogen sources. The technology will advance the hydrogen economy.<br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of a technology for hydrogen production from water splitting. The proposed catalytic water-splitting technology has demonstrated enhanced performance with greatly reduced use of noble metals. In the existing market, customer needs arise from specific requirements to provide pure hydrogen production from renewable sources that help to effectively manage energy consumption, provide a clean environment with zero pollution, as well as provide high-energy efficiency. Hydrogen production from water splitting has the potential to address many of these challenges. However, high material costs, low efficiency, and poor durability constitute major barriers to industrial and residential applications. The proposed hydrogen production technology in this project will overcome these barriers by significantly decreasing the amount of noble metals in the catalysts. The reduction of the loading of noble metals in the catalysts without sacrificing the activity and durability will reduce the materials cost for manufacturing water splitting system.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this I-Corps project, the team has conducted extensive customer discovery and identified the potential customers to determine the commercialization feasibility of an efficient hydrogen production technology based on water splitting.  This technology helps pure hydrogen consumers who suffer from the pain of high cost, low efficiency, inconvenience of hydrogen sources and carbon monoxide impurity in hydrogen.  Customer needs arise from specific requirements to provide pure hydrogen production from renewable sources that could effectively manage the energy consumption, clean environment, and zero pollution for residential and industrial applications. However, high material costs, low efficiency, and poor durability constitute major barriers to industrial and residential applications. The team consists of entrepreneurial lead, co-entrepreneurial lead, technical lead, and industrial mentor, focusing on customer discovery to identify the market opportunity and develop a business model for commercializing a new catalytic hydrogen production technology from water splitting. The team has conducted more than 200 customer interviews including onsite, in person, zoom meetings, phone calls, and trade show/conference interviews.  The team interviewed CEOs, salesperson, program directors, production Managers, business owners, product engineers, and technical leaders in companies such as Toyota, Phillips 66, Airgas, Air liquid, Sunrun, Panasonic, Shimadzu, Praxair, etc. There are several customer segments for water splitting technology for hydrogen production, including on-site hydrogen device manufacturers and financial managers which are experiencing problems with the cost, efficiency and durability for the current technology and are looking for alternative materials.  Several hypotheses have been tested, including how the increased energy efficiency and system lifetime and reduced system cost help the development of the efficient storage of extra solar and wind energy in the form of hydrogen, and how the needs to replace the current hydrogen sources can meet the requirement of system cost.  There is a clear need of further improvement of the technology to gain significant competition edges with emerging new battery technologies.  The team has also worked a prototype demonstration of the water electrolysis modules.  The potential commercial impact stems from increasing societal interests and market needs in clean energy and clean environment. Major impacts include the commercialization of a sustainable and clean on-site hydrogen source as a substitute for hydrogen from fossil fuel reforming. The technology will benefit the water splitting manufacturers who currently suffer from high manufacturing costs associated with expensive catalyst materials and manufacturing, low efficiency, and short lifetime in operation. The technology will benefit pure-hydrogen consumers who suffer from the impurity from current hydrogen sources.  The project has also assessed the commercialization plan to bring this technology to the market for pursuing entrepreneurship and technology commercialization. The training of young entrepreneurs in the business model development throughout the customer discovery has been an important element for the development of a refined business model and value proposition.  Some of the lessons learnt in this project have also been incorporated into part of the team in graduate and undergraduate classrooms and in research laboratories.  The industrial partnership is also an effective vehicle to train students and researchers for better preparation in technology commercialization in the sustainable energy market.    

 

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2023
Modified by: Susan Lu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In this I-Corps project, the team has conducted extensive customer discovery and identified the potential customers to determine the commercialization feasibility of an efficient hydrogen production technology based on water splitting. This technology helps pure hydrogen consumers who suffer from the pain of high cost, low efficiency, inconvenience of hydrogen sources and carbon monoxide impurity in hydrogen. Customer needs arise from specific requirements to provide pure hydrogen production from renewable sources that could effectively manage the energy consumption, clean environment, and zero pollution for residential and industrial applications. However, high material costs, low efficiency, and poor durability constitute major barriers to industrial and residential applications. The team consists of entrepreneurial lead, co-entrepreneurial lead, technical lead, and industrial mentor, focusing on customer discovery to identify the market opportunity and develop a business model for commercializing a new catalytic hydrogen production technology from water splitting. The team has conducted more than 200 customer interviews including onsite, in person, zoom meetings, phone calls, and trade show/conference interviews. The team interviewed CEOs, salesperson, program directors, production Managers, business owners, product engineers, and technical leaders in companies such as Toyota, Phillips 66, Airgas, Air liquid, Sunrun, Panasonic, Shimadzu, Praxair, etc. There are several customer segments for water splitting technology for hydrogen production, including on-site hydrogen device manufacturers and financial managers which are experiencing problems with the cost, efficiency and durability for the current technology and are looking for alternative materials. Several hypotheses have been tested, including how the increased energy efficiency and system lifetime and reduced system cost help the development of the efficient storage of extra solar and wind energy in the form of hydrogen, and how the needs to replace the current hydrogen sources can meet the requirement of system cost. There is a clear need of further improvement of the technology to gain significant competition edges with emerging new battery technologies. The team has also worked a prototype demonstration of the water electrolysis modules. The potential commercial impact stems from increasing societal interests and market needs in clean energy and clean environment. Major impacts include the commercialization of a sustainable and clean on-site hydrogen source as a substitute for hydrogen from fossil fuel reforming. The technology will benefit the water splitting manufacturers who currently suffer from high manufacturing costs associated with expensive catalyst materials and manufacturing, low efficiency, and short lifetime in operation. The technology will benefit pure-hydrogen consumers who suffer from the impurity from current hydrogen sources. The project has also assessed the commercialization plan to bring this technology to the market for pursuing entrepreneurship and technology commercialization. The training of young entrepreneurs in the business model development throughout the customer discovery has been an important element for the development of a refined business model and value proposition. Some of the lessons learnt in this project have also been incorporated into part of the team in graduate and undergraduate classrooms and in research laboratories. The industrial partnership is also an effective vehicle to train students and researchers for better preparation in technology commercialization in the sustainable energy market.
